ratings.question_text: Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments: None
It was a virtual, seminar-sized class, but often was a live lecture style

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course? (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: This course was a good review of neuroanatomy and a good introduction to MRI methods and techniques. We were taught how to critically analyze research publications, how to improve research designs, and how to create our own research proposal. Other techniques like literature review and meta-analyses were taught and used.

I loved this course! We learned about how to conduct research-- specifically neuroscientific research-- through hands-on experience and through lecture discussions, so the whole course was very engaging. We were able to conduct our own experiments, which was a cool opportunity. We often learned about the different stages of conducting research with a different given theme for lecture, so the material was always new and engaging.
Learned a lot about critiquing scientific papers and about different methods in neuroscience research  especially fMRI
Neuroscientific research methods like fMRI and study design
I learned how to critique research papers and methods used in research designs.

I learned to critically engage with empirical literature in the field of cognitive neuroscience, including learning fmri techniques and technical contextual using info and how to perform meta analyses.
I learned so much about how to analyze and understand research papers, which is an extremely important and useful skill. I also learned a lot about various imaging techniques.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved? (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments:
The professor and TA were both very understanding and helpful. Assignments were not very difficult, yet, we learned a lot. Assignments were engaging and informative. The lectures were very clear despite having complicated concepts. 
I think that because this was the first time the course was taught and because of the online format, it felt like there was no clear set schedule, but this was not a problem because the professor and TA were always there to help and guide us through the assignments.

Honestly thought it was great! No real suggestions for improvement, except maybe it would be helpful if there was an outlined structure/timeline for our final project, instead of it seeming like a last minute sort of thing.

Strengths: Stephanie, the small discussion-type format, great assessments that helped solidify the content
No weaknesses
The professor made the class very engaging while also teaching us the necessary material. Not many classes that I've experienced has been able to do that.

Strengths: cool information, knowledgeable and nice professor
Weaknesses: too fast paced so you leave with a surface level of understanding of different things, not enough conversation in class (often too lecture-y)
I really enjoyed this course! It was engaging and Stephanie always found a way to make it fun.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: The empathy Professor Lazzaro showed was one of the practices in this class which improved my learning experience. There was always a direct line of communication between the students and the professor. Additionally, the emphasis placed on learning rather than grading in the last few assignments was very helpful.
Good use of raise hand features etc, professor was on top of tech stuff. Could have engaged students more actively because class felt really long at times.
I think she succeeded in being able to keep us engaged, even virtually!

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I would recommend this course to another student. Professor Lazzaro is an amazing professor and was one of the few understanding professors during COVID. The lectures deal with complicated concepts but are presented in a very clear way. There are very few assignments in this class but you will still learn a lot.  If you are interested in research designs or neuroanatomy at all I definitely recommend this course if you're able to get in.
Yes, ABSOLUTELY! Especially if it's with Lazzaro! It isn't too much work, you learn a lot, and you get some firsthand experience conducting small-scale research!
Yes! Very interesting and engaging. Really good methods class for majors
If interested specifically in neuroscientific research methods like fMRI

Definitely!  The professor and teaching fellow were both great. I enjoyed this class so much and learned a lot. The professor was also very understanding of the circumstances students were going through this semester.
Yes
Yes! I really enjoyed it.
Yes, Steph is an amazing professor and she really cares about her students' learning. You will learn a lot about neuroscience and psychology experimental procedures, and how to analyze fMRIs.
